Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said.Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamersfor Marceille, Gibralter, Plymouth, and London are intended to leave Port Saidafter the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindle Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive Passengers can go on board the evening before
The express steamer usually reaches Brindial on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m and arriving to London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindial or via Marseille.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or MArseilles.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcotta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOB (for Mount Sinai) as required.

ENTERIC FEVER AND THE ARMY.

From a military and strategic point of view there can be no doubt that the proper organization, training, and equipment of the British Army in peace with a view to preventing the military disaster which in the past have constantly fallen upon Armies unprepared to meet their onset, is a question of pressing ungenos in the army. In this connection great interest has been aroused, in the army and beyond, by the thorough manner in which the object has been treated by Dr. Leigh Canney in his recent lecture to a large military and medical audience at the Royal United Service Institution Space alone prevents adequate consideration of the important scheme Dr. Leigh Canney has again brought prominently before the army, and we refer our reader, for a detailed report of his scheme to the “Times” of November 9, where three to four columns are occupied by this subject and Dr. Leigh Canney's reply to Sir T. Gallway. That Dr. Leigh Canney was able to produce more evidence from the reports of the Army Medical Department to show that the Army was “sanitarily untrained and unprotected, in an effective sense, both in peace and in war,” will doubtless afford material for serious consideration by the army generally. Snob a condition of the army, if called upon to take the field, cannot, we presume, be in' accordance with the beat endeavors of the Royal A-my Medical Corps, and probably therefore indicate, difficulties either actually experienced or expected by this Corps from those in authority consequent on their neglect to realize the extreme, importance of the mea­sures sanitation demands. The Royal Army Medical Corps, being aware of the frequent difficulties before them in securing the reforms they may desire will nonetheless welcome as an advocate Dr. Leigh Canney, to whom in the past the usual official reply of "entirely im- practicable” has acted only as an incentive to | further efforts to overcome official apathy the result that the "impractical" has been actually carried out within a few months of its declared impracticability.

We regret, therefore, the tone of 8ir T. Gallway’s letter to the "Time*" both as regards Dr. Leigh Canney's scheme and his reutterance to Sir Fredrick Treves, for both have alike rendered great service to the army. A scheme fashioned so far in advance of anything yet known or practiced in armies—though the Japanese army, two yean after its publication, is found practically adopting its main essentials with very excellent results may naturally arouse opposition at first from those that have not properly studied the data, figures, and facts produced in its support The criticism, however, is doubtless welcomed tending to strengthen the arguments in favor of the, scheme proposed, as far as we are aware.

Dr. Leigh Canney's scheme has met with practically unanimous approval and strong support from large audiences, military and medical, whenever it has, been considered. It must be remembered that sanitation should not be regarded as the responsible executive duty of any one part of the army alone, such as the Royal Army Medical Corps. Effective sanitation is the duty of the whole army. The training and instruction of the army in methods, the recording of results attained by officers with a view of recognition for success, is the function of a Sanitary Bureau or branch of the R. A. M. C.

We have observed a tendency amongst officers of the R. A. M. C. to assume that because Dr. Leigh Canney has insisted on the paramount necessity of supplying only sterile water or fluid to armies, as an essential basis of all or any sanit -ry scheme, he therefore recognizes only a waterborne origin or enteric fever. Such interpretation of his opinion would not be in accordance with his published scientific papers. This authority states that “if the liquid avenues, are protected there will be no epidemic; only sporadic cases can occur. If these are isolated the camp will again be free and remain so," and that "if through imperfect protection of the fluid avenues the invasion of enteric is permitted and is fully established, then the subsidiary avenues with become increasingly important." This protection of on Fluid Avenue, in this scheme is secur­ed by sterilization by heat, as being the only absolutely reliable method, and therefore unless this has been done, and by specially trained men, the fluid avenues cannot be considered as closed to the bacillus. The me­thod, of sterilization of drinking water carried out in barracks in India and South Africa stand absolutely condemned by the official reports of the Army Medical Department, as Dr. Leigh Canney points out and states, that "to expect that a poor ignorant outcast Bhisti’ without training is, for a mere pittance, going to interest him, well in the details of the sterile drinking water of your barrack, by order of the regimental authorities,' and what is far more important, conduct you safely through the turmoil of war to the front, and there keep you efficient in the last thing in quixotism," hence Sit T. Gallway could hardly expect to state otherwise than that "all our schemes, for sterilization by boiling or otherwise have had no effect.” Once the army has placed the service of sterilized drinking water beyond discussion this scheme then proceeds to close any suitable remedies, the avenue, by contact, any flies, and possibly by dust, which afford be possible sporadic cases. We cannot follow in detail the mass, of evidence produces by Dr. Leigh Canney in support of each essential condition of his scheme, but it deserves the closest attention from the Army Medical Department and the army generally, for there can be no question that that the control of enteric and allied diseases which form by far the greater proportion of that ‘disease’ which in the experience of the last fifty years of wars, sends the soldier twenty-five times more frequently into hospital than the weapons of the enemy, cannot fail to be of the utmost importance to armies. We trust it may not need another war, and the even greater sani­tary disasters Lord Robert predicts, to bring home to the army the importance of thorough sanitary organization. Meanwhile there is the risk- as the "Times" has recently pointed out "for fear of being 'extreme' they stop short of being efficient"—of partial measures being adopted. The suppression of enteric fever is not to be attained except by thorough, careful, and continuous methods; as Dr. Leigh Canney has stated, “it is a campaign within a campaign."

div.head: EGYPTIAN GAZETTE, MONDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1905.
TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICATION CUT OF
div.p: HUGE FIRE AT MOSCOW
St. Petersburg. December 2.
The number of officers of the Guard arrested at Tsarakoe Selo upon, suspicion of having arranged a coup d’état is increasing.

General Chouknin reports that the bailors and soldiers were deluded by the revolutionary leaders who led them to believe that they could remain faithful to their Emperor while pretending demands, provided that they need no violence. (Reuter)
Paris, December 2.
The Russian Agency contradicts the rumor, emanating from Berlin, of the attempt on the life of the Tsar by a Grand Duke, the Tear being wounded in the hand by a revolver shot.
(Hava)
Sevastopol, December 2.
The dock hands have gone on strike. (H.)
Warsaw, December 3.
A private railway telegram reports that a huge incendiary fire is raging at Moscow. This is the only message received on Saturday. R.)
Kieff, December 3.
Serious rioting has taken place here and fighting has occurred between the Cossack* and the mutinous sappers. Some scores of casualties are reported.

The Jews of Odessa have succeeded in send­ing a message to the frontier imploring the civilized nations to prevent an unparalleled catastrophe, as they declare the troops are being incited to exterminate them. (Reutier), Paris, December 3.
All telegraphic communication with Russia is absolutely cut off. News received by way of the frontier states that serious disorders con­tinue at St. Petersburg. (Hava*
EFFECT ON PARIS BOURSE.
- London, December 2.
Telegraphic communication with St Peters-' burg is completely interrupted.

'The situation in Russia is being reacted on the Paris Bour-e, where there has been a heavy drop in Russian securities, leading to general weakness, owing to the fact that Paris holds £1,000,000,000 of Russian stocks. Anxiety is already being expressed about the payment of coupons. (Reuter)
RIOTING IN BRITISH GUIANA.
GOVERNOR BESIEGED.
Georgetown (British Guiana), December 2.

The strike of the dockers has led to two days’ rioting and looting here. The officers of the local forces and others are besieged in one of the public buildings. The gunboats S ppbo and Diamond are anxiously awaited from S’. Thomas. (Reuter)
Georgetown December 3.
There is a lull in the rioting. The police have rescued the besieged governor and the other officials. The rioters’ casualties were 27. Theblack troops behaved splendidly. (Reuter)
ENGLAND AND GERMANY.
TOWARDS AN UNDERSTANDING.
London, December 3.

The German Ambassador, speaking at the Lyceum Club, said that the shadow of enmity between Great Britain and Germany was due to an artificially created ill-feeling. The German Government would welcome any move meant to promote good relations, and would gladly respond to any friendly demonstration on the part of England.
(Reuter)
THE TURKISH SITUATION.
Paris. December 3.
The international squadron will leave today for Tenedos. (Havas)
NEW SPANISH CABINET
Madrid^ December 2.
M. Moret has reformed the Cabinet. (H.)
football at crystal palace.
Telegraph at Mena. ,
A telegraph office has been opened at Mena House Hotel
Our Cairo Office. "
The Cairo office of the “Egyptian Gazette” is situated in 8baria Zervndachi, opposite the Agricultural Bank. Our Cairo Correspondent is Mr. Philip P. Graves.
Ibrahimieh Canal.
The public are informed that the closing ofthe Ibrahimieh Canal from the regulator bridge at Sharahna to its termination has been post­poned from the 15th to the 20th instead.
A Canard.
Some rumors were current at Alexandra this morning as to a serious riot having occur­red at Abbasaieh. It appears to be a canard, for no confirmation is obtainable from Cairo.
Suez Canal.
Ten vessels passed through the Canal on the:-Oth olt. Of which 7 were British, 2 German 1 Dutch. The total receipts for the month of November were frs. 9 688,796, from 326 ships.
Provincial Councils.
The provincial councils of Charkieh. Dakah- lieh, and Galionbieh have been convoked for the 8th, 9th, and 10th inst., respectively, by Khedivial decree, to examine next year’s irrigation programme.
Ghozireh-Boulac Bridge.

In our notice of the new bridge which is to unite Ghezireh and Boulac we stated that the bridge would end on the Ghezireh side about two metres above the hotel. This should have been two hundred metres.
Accident,

Owadalla Eff. Aryan, chief clerk of the Registration Department at Cairo, met his death on Saturday while getting off a train at Embideh, before the train had come to a standstill. He fell under the carriages and was terribly mutilated.
Orwat el-Woska.

Ahmed Djalal el Din Pasha has presented L.E. 50 to the Muslim Benevolent Society Al Orwat el Wuska” and has also promised to endow the society with some estates of the wakf which he intends to consecrate to the memory of his late wife, the Princess Ishmat Hanuem.
Court Martial.

Before a general court-martial held at Khar­toum on the 2nd ult., E. Mulazim Awal Ahmed Effeudt Shukri, 15th Sudanese, was arranged on the following charges: -- (i) In a document made by him, knowingly making a false state­ment; (ii.) Absenting himself without leave. The Court found the prisoner guilty of the first charge, and not guilty of the second charge, and sentenced him to take rank and precedence in the Army as if his appointment at Mulazim Awal in the Army bore date of the 28th August, 1903, and to be severely reprimanded. The Sirdar confirmed the finding and sentence of the Court, which was pro mulgated on the 11th ult.
Lord Cromer paid a visit yesterday morning to the Orthodox Coptic Patriarch. »

Lady Anne Blunt, the wife of Mr. Wilfrid Blunt, arrives at Alexandria this afternoon by the North German Lloyd Schleswig. Mr. Wilfrid Blunt is not coming to Egypt this season owing to illness. His condition, however, has, lately shown considerable improvement.
Admiral the Hon. Hedworth Lambton and Sir George Warrender, Bart, dined with Sir Vincent Corbett on Friday and returned to Mena House Hotel in the evening.
Admiral Lambton had intended staying a couple of days only at Mena House Hotel, but has prolonged his stay there for another few days.

When Admiral Lambton and Sir George Warrender, who had been out for a camel ride after lunch on Saturday, alighted on the square of Mena House Hotel, a whole crowd of visitors were to be seen taking snapshots of the naval hero.
Lieut.-Col. and Mrs. Ludlow have taken up their residence for the season at Mena House Hotel.
Dr. W. P. Graham returns to-Cairo today from a tour of inspection in Lower Egypt.

The visitors staying at the Hotel Moeris, the charming encampment on Lake Moeris, are the Rev. R. am Mrs. MacInnes, Miss MacInnes, Miss Dora MacInnes, Cairo; Miss Braine Hartnell, Old Cairo; Dr. Pain, Old Cairo; Miss Jackson, and Miss Warburton, Helouan.
LATEST FROM CONSTANTINOPLE.

Our London Correspondent writes : — The coming marriage between Mr. Percy Wilfrid Maobell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, Cairo, and Countess Victoria Gleichen, better known as Countess Valda, second daughter of the late Prince Victor of H henlobe- Langenbnurg, and of the Princess, who stil1 survives, is now the chief topic of conversation in social circles. The wadding has been fixed for Tuesday, the 5th December, at noon, and will take place at the Chapel Royal, 8t. James’ Palace His Majesty the King has signified his retention of being present.

The ceremony will be conducted by the Archbishop of Canterbury, assisted by the Sub- dean of the Chapel Royal, 8t James's Palace. Archbishop will be particularly attractive to the select few who will be able to gain admit­tance to the chapel, which unfortunately accommodated a very limited number. The service will be fully choral, and Sir Walter Parratt, Mus. Doc., M.V.O., will preside at the organ. Owing to the residence of the Countess at the Palace itself there can, of course, be no procession.

Mr. Machell has selected the Hon. Harold Willoughby to be his best pan, and the bride will be attended by the following bridesmaids: Miss Lavinia Spencer, and Miss Loelia Ponsonby, and Master Derrick Amory and Master Patrick Holme (nephew of Mr. Machell) will act as pages. The bride will be given away by her brother, Count Gleichen.

As regards the reception, which will be of a brilliant character, this will take place on Monday' the 4th December, the day before the wadding, in the Armoury, St. James’s Palace. Numerous distinguished guests have been invited.

On the wedding day itself, in consequence of the small number who can, owing to the smallness of the chapel, be accommodated, there will be no special reception, and the bride and bridegroom will start for their honey­moon on that day.

It is understood that Mr. Machell will, how­ever, shortly return to Egypt, where he will receive the congratulations of all his friends, and where the Countess, owing not only to her princely birth, but also to her charming personality and her brilliant accomplishments, particularly in music, will be highly appreciated, and where, by right' of birth as well as talent, she will take the highest potboy among the elite of the society of Egypt, and the courtesies due to her exalted rank are sore to be accorded to her. It is truly a notable event in the history of the Civil Service of Egypt.
THE CAIRO 8RASON.

The band on Shepheard’s verandah was the usual attraction on Saturday afternoon. Mrs. Rome was there in one of the very newest sailor hats—with a wideow crown surround­ed with roses and perched at an impossible but essentially chic angle with an enor­mous cachepeigne of tulle and feathers. Mr. and Mrs. Stout were having tea, the latter in a very pretty white frock with much handsome lace insertion, and a small velvet hat Mrs. Carton de Wiart and Miss James were entertaining quite a party, Mr., Mrs. and Miss Joseph being among the party.
There was the usual small dance at the same hotel during the evening; but not many beyond the hotel visitors were present.
DESERT AIR AS A RHEUMATISM CURE.

A German physician has discovered that the air of the Egyptian desert is about as free from bacterial life as the Polar regime on the high seas. Tubercle bacilli are killed when exposed six hours in the sunlight. He con­siders the desert especially suitable for the cure of rheumatism and patients suffering from kidney diseases.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The Moss liner Menepthuh sailed from Liverpool on Saturday and is due here about the 15th inst.
The Moss liner Tabor nailed hence for Liver­pool, via Malta, yesterday morning with pas­sengers. mails, and general cargo, including 5,095 bales cotton.
The Moss liner Philae arrived yesterday morning from Glasgow, via Pembroke Dock, Gibraltar and Malta.
The Moss liner Rameses arrived this morning from Liverpool via Gibraltar and Malta.

News comes from Constantinople to the effect that the Grand Cadi of Egypt, Sheikh Yehia, has been dismissed by an Imperial Iradi, and that Shaikh Djemal El-Din Eff. Grand Cadi of the Hedjaz has been appointed to replace him in the Cadi-hip of Egypt.
The household of Sheikh Yehia have receiv­ed instructions to prepare themselves for hasty departure to Constantinople.

It was the Khedive’s prerogative (“Al Moa- yad" remarks) to select the Grand Cadi of Egypt, who receives his official appointment from the Sultan; but this time our contempor­ary thinks his Highness will acquiesce in the new appointment, after calling the Mahein’s attention to this prerogative.
We understand that nothing is known offi­cially as to the reason of the Grand Cadi’s decision to remain in Turkey, which is con­firmed.
THE KHEDIVE.
H. H. the Khedive gave audience to his Ministers on Saturday morning at 10 p m. and at 11 a.m. gave private audience to Lord Cromer.
The Khedive arrived at Sidi Gaber station from Cairo yesterday evening at 8.30 o’clock and proceeded to Montazah Palace, where his Highness spent the night.
This morning his Highness went to Mariout to visit his estates there.
FUAD PASHA’S SONS.

Kamel Bey Efferdi, the youngest son of Marshal Fuad Pasha, who is imprisoned in Damascus, arrived hero a few days ago and proceeded to Cairo. Kamel Bey and his brother, Rashid Bey, were military students in Berlin, and after finishing their studies intended to return home. But hearing that by doing so they would probably be exiled, as are their father and eldest brother, the two brothers agreed that one of them should return to Constantinople, and that if he fell into trouble the other brother was to avoid Turkey. Thus Rashid Buy proceeded to the Turkish Capital alone, where he was degraded from his military rank and banished to Konin. Having heard of his brother’s fate Kamel Bey left Berlin for Egypt.
LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.

The Legislative Council met at 10 a.m. on Saturday at the Ministry of Public Works to examine the proposed Budget for 1906. The examination of the Budget and of the draft decree relating to the examination of fikis was postponed till the next meeting, which to be held on the 14th inst. The Legislative Council approved the measure for fixing the boundaries of the towns of Ghizeh, Benha, and Mit Ghemr for the payment of the tax on buildings, the project, du decret relative to the Faoned el Iltezem and that concerning the payment of next year’s date tax The Council expressed the hope that the Government would be able to see its way to abolish this tax.
EGYPTIAN ARMY.

El Mira’ai H. G. K Matchett Bey has been appointed Senior Military Officer. Cairo, vice El Lewa Lord E. H Cecil Pasha, D. S. 0. To date 4-11-05. Matchett Bey still retains his position as officer commanding Cairo District and Commandant Military School.

Leave of absence on private affairs, has been granted to El Miralai Dickinson Bey, Governor Blue Nile Province, El Ksimakam Connolly Bey, and officer commanding 1st Sudanese, and Et Bimbashi Peroival, lst Battalion.
H. the Khedive has been graciously pleased to approve of the promotion of El Bimbathi G. S. Nickeison, Sudan Government, to be Kamakam.

The following transfers have been approved, from dates stated:—B1 Bimbashi C. V. N. Percival, 1st Battalion, to 4th Battalion, 26-11-05; El Bimbashi J. H. M. Arden 4th Battalion, to 18th Sudanese 26-11-05 ; El Bombashi C, G. M. Bonfield, 13th Sudanese to 1st Battalion, 26-11-05.
A NEW HERE8Y.

The Coptic Patriarch at Cairo has declared himself an opponent of the new heresy which has arisen in Abyssinia. The monks of the Abyssinian monastery of Bislu have taken to teaching the simple folk around them that the doctrine of the Trinity is an error, and that each of the Three Persons is independent of the others in his divine attributes. The Coptic Patriarch at once denounced this teaching as heresy, but Menelik has taken the side of his monks, and a national Abyssinian has just de­clared in favor of three gods.
PRINCE LEOPOLD.

H.R H. Prince Leopold of Battenberg and suite. Accompanied by some friends, went out to Mena House Hotel for luncheon on Saturday and made use of the well-known stable there afterwards for a ride in the desert.
ENGLAND BEATEN.
London, December 2.
New Zealand beat England by 15 to 0 at the Crystal Palace. (Reuter)
London, December 3.
Football. The attendance at the Crystal Palace was 60,000. The ground was muddy and the ball greasy. The English were out passed. (Reuter)

div.head: TO-MORROW’S ARRANGEMENTS.
div.p: ENGLAND BEATEN.
London, December 2.
New Zealand beat England by 15 to 0 at the Crystal Palace. (Reuter)
London, December 3.
Football. The attendance at the Crystal Palace was 60,000. The ground was muddy and the ball greasy. The English were out passed. (Reuter)

We much regret to announce the tragic death of Dr. Joseph Sierra, physician to the Egyptian Railway Administration for the last twenty years. Dr. Sierra was in the best of health on Saturday and he spent a portion of the day in settling his private affairs and making preparations for death. He apparently committed suicide on Saturday night by open­ing an artery and on Sunday morning was found dead in his bed. The tragedy is enhanced by the fact that his wife arrived yesterday morning at Alexandria by the Florio-Rubattino steamer. Dr. Sierra was an Italian Jew by origin and was about 62 years of age. He was raised to the rank of Cavaliere some years ago by the King of Italy. The funeral took place this morning and was largely attended, for the doctor was much respected and liked by all classes of the community.
TRAGEDY AT ALEXANDRIA.
DEATH OF DR. SIERRA

We much regret to announce the tragic death of Dr. Joseph Sierra, physician to the Egyptian Railway Administration for the last twenty years. Dr. Sierra was in the best of health on Saturday and he spent a portion of the day in settling his private affairs and making preparations for death. He apparently committed suicide on Saturday night by open­ing an artery and on Sunday morning was found dead in his bed. The tragedy is enhanced by the fact that his wife arrived yesterday morning at Alexandria by the Florio-Rubattino steamer. Dr. Sierra was an Italian Jew by origin and was about 62 years of age. He was raised to the rank of Cavaliere some years ago by the King of Italy. The funeral took place this morning and was largely attended, for the doctor was much respected and liked by all classes of the community.
DEATH OF SIR CLINTON DAWKINS.
London, December 2.
Sir Clinton Dawkins is dead. (Reuter)

The announcement of Sir Clinton Dawkins’ death has come as a great shock to the many friends which the late Under Secretary of State at the Ministry of Finance had in this country. He was only 45 years of age and to all appear­ances had a brilliant future before him.

Sir Clinton Edward Dawkins, K.C.B., was born 1859, in London, and was educated at Cheltenham and Baliol, where he graduated M A., taking honors in Moderations and Greats. Sir Clinton acted as Private Secretary to Lord Crop of the India Office in 1886, and Private Secretary to Mr. Guschen, when Chan­cellor of the Exchequer, in 1889. He was a representative of the Peruvian Corporation ii Sooth America, 1891; was Under-Secretary for Finance in Egypt, 1895, and Financial Member of the Council of the Governor-General of India, lt-99. He became a partner in Messrs. J. S. Morgan & Co. in 1900 and was Chairman of the Committee of War' Office Re-organize- tion, 1901. Lord Milner’s famous ‘E gland in Egypt” contains an appendix from Sir Clinton’s pen. He married in 1888, Louise Johnston.
THE RAILWAY WASHOUT
The following telegram was received on Saturday too late for publication in that day's issue:—
Normal working has been resumed over bridge at Abou el Nomros station. Passengers will not have to change carriages. Trains are, however, subject to fifteen minutes’ delay.
COIN MOULDS IN EGYPT.

At the last meeting of the Royal Numisma­tic Society, held in London on November 16, Mr. J. G Milne communicated a paper on Roman coin-moulds from Egypt, in which be described the use of these moulds and the manner in which coins were e*at in them. This process appears to have been a cire perdue one. The moulds were made from coins of the beginning of the fourth century, mostly struck at the mint of Alexandria. In the course of recent excavations at Oxyrynchus it was ascertained that the proportion of cast coins discovered there was one in five.—In connection with the paper the President and Mr. G.P, Hill exhibited a series of similar moulds, some of which had been found in England, the others coming from Egypt.
HIBEH PAPYRI.
Part I. of the Hibeh Papyri is now being printed, and will be issued in June next. The volume consists of papyri of the third century b.c. from mummy cartonnage, including many classical fragments.
ROYAL NAVY LI8T.

To anyone in any way connected with the Royal Navy the “Royal Navy List and Naval Recorder” (Witherby & Co.) is invaluable as a book of reference. The issue for the last quarter of 1905 has been brought thoroughly up to date. Lists of officers and of ships have a permanent value from which nothing can detract, but the value of the publication has been considerably enhanced since the incorporation, this year, of the Naval Recorder, which was designed in order to keep readers informed of a larger proportion of the movements and affairs of the Royal Navy than had hitherto been attempted. The “Current History of the Royal Navy,” which is one of >be features, is parked with important events, brief and easily read. A subject of pre-eminent importance alike to the lay English men and the officer is that of commission of ships, and a summary of these has been compiled with evident care. Other records and tables complete the new undertaking, which will no doubt be found of the almost utility and interest.
SPORT AND PLAY.
FOOTBALL.
A football match will take place to-morrow between H. M. S. Carnarvon and the E. T. C. Staff on Moharrem Bey Common, kindly lent by the St. Andrews F. C. Kick-off 3:30.

div.head: EGYPTIAN FINANCE. BANKING AND LAND COMPANIES.
div.p: The following is extracted from the city article of the “Daily Telegraph” of the 25th ulto. Much of it is of course ancient history to many of our readers but as an interesting and succinct resume it deserves reproduction: — During the last twelve months a good deal of attention has been paid to Egyptian bankand land companies which is not surprising when regard is had to the improvement in the condition of the condition of the fellaheen and the increasing prosperity of the country. The progress of Egypt has undoubtedly been hastened by the facilities afforded by the new undertakings but there are signs that, in some instances, speculation had carried things along rather too rapidly, and that a reaction in the near future is highly probable. The oldest of the Egyptian banks it the Bank of Egypt, which was incor­porated in 1856 by Royal charter, and recon­structed and registered as a limited company in 1887. Its capital is £1,000,000, in shares of £15, of which £11 10s per share is called up. The dividends have steadily improved from 9 per cent. For 1*9-4 to 16 percent, for 1904, and the shares now stand at 33, after being as high as 36. The next in seniority is the Anglo- Egyptian Bank, which was registered in 1864, and reconstructed in 188', the capital being £1.500, 000 in shares of £15, of which £5 is paid. This bank’s dividends have risen in the last ten years from 6 per cent to, 12j per cent. For each to the past two financial years ended on Ang. 31, and the shares are quoted at 13}. But these banks have substantial reserve funds, and np to 1898 had a practical monopoly of the banking business in Egypt In that year Sir Ernest Cassel came on the scene and started his operations by forming the Irrigation Investment Corporation, with a nominal share capital of £100,000 and power to issue Debenture* or similar securities* for the purpose of acquiring the pay warrants according to Messrs. John Aird and Co. in connection with the great Nile barrage scheme. Egyptian Government Poor per Cent. Irrigation Trust certificates, of which there are £2,590.900 outstanding, are well known as «u excellent investment, and are quoted at about: 104.

Sir Ernest Castel's next step was, in conjunction with a syndicate comprising Mesers. E Cattani, E. Cronier, and Sanieh Company, and to acquire the Daira Estates from the Egyptian Government, and to form the Diara Sanieh Company. Out of the sales of these lands the whole of the £6,431,570 Daira Sanieh Govern­ment bonds have been redeemed, and the company has made very large profits. The agreement was that the property, or sufficient to pay off the Government bond, should be Bold within seven years, provided the sales could be effected at a net profit of 20 per cent. The capital of the company was £600,000 in 118,000. Ordinary shares of £5 each, and

10,000. Deferred shares of £1 each. After pay­ment of 5-per cent, on the Ordinary shares half the surplus goes to the Egyptian Govern­ment, and of the remaining moiety the Or­dinary shares get 60 per cent and the Deferred 40 per cent. From 1899 to 1902 the dividend on the Ordinary shares was 3s., for 1903 it was 4s and in 1904 it was 8s per share. In October last, It will be remembered that after repayment of the Government bunds distributions were made of £ 0 on the Ordinary and £78 on the Deferred. The price of Daira Sanieh Ordinary have ranged from 7 1/2 to 30, the pre­sent price, after deduction of the £ 0 re­cently paid, being 17 3/4, while the Deferred shares, which have fluctuated between 35 and 185, are now quoted at 108, ex the £78 above referred to. It will thus be seen what an enormous success the company has proved. The next company, issued under the auspices of Sir Ernest Cassel, was the National Bank of Egypt, formed as an Egyptian joint-stock company in June, 1898, with a capital of £3,000,000 in shares of £0 each. So far 250,000 shares have Dean issued, and the present quotation is about 25, the highest point having been 28 1/4. The dividend for last year was 7 per cent

In May 1902, the Agricultural Bank of Egypt was floated as an Egyptian joint-stock company, to make advances on mortgage to small farmers, and it is practically a subsidiary of the National Bank of Egypt The original capital was £2,500,000, consisting of 125,000 4 per cent. Preference shares of £10 each.

Ordinary shares of £5, and 2,000 deferred shares of £5 each. In September last the ordinary capital was doubled by a further issue of 248,000 shares. The fully-paid ordinary shares, which have been as high as 14 ¼ are now quoted at 9 3/8.Various other land, banking, and finance companies have been recently created, mostly of a speculative character, and in which little interest is taken in the London market. Among these may be mentioned the Land Bank of Egypt, with a capital of £500,000 in 97,000 Ordinary and 5,000 Founders’ shares of £5 each. This bank was promoted this year by the Anglo-Foreign Banking Company, and the Ordinary shares stand at 8 ½, after being as high as 10, The Union Foncier of Egypt, with a capital of £500.000, was also issued quite recently, and the shares, after being 3 premium, are now nominally 1 premium. Yet another similar concern is the Egyptian Estate and Finance Company, of which 250,000 shares of 1 have been subscribe. Here again after being up to 2, the shares are now quoted about par. It will be noticed that in all the recent quotation prices have fallen considerably from the top and this fact probably explains the uneasiness lately felt concerning the financial position in Egypt. That there is a great future for Egypt no one will den, but, as the chairman of Anglo-Egyptian Bank stated at the meeting, competition is becoming excessive, it will be a pity if financial disaster is courted by the over production of speculative companies
LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits- free discussion.
SAVE US FROM OUR FRIENDS.
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette
“A citizen of no moan city, I beseech this suffer me to speak unto the people.”

Sir,—In quoting the above words, which were spoken by one of the finest men the world ever produced, I do so in no irre­verent spirit, although 1 have no pretention to refer them to snob lofty aims as did their author. A few years since I once read in your columns, on some question referring. I think, to public infraction, that we who.use the English language have done more than any other people to endeavour to make the Book from which I now quote, the guide of our daily life I sincerely believe that we have rightly done so; though many people appear to think that the Bible should only be used on Sunday or quoted only on religious questions. I think on the contrary that we may often profit by its teaching, even in the most mundane and frivolous acts of our lives.

Your columns have lately teemed with a correspondence referring originally to the water supply of Alexandria, during which several very unpleasant questions have been raked up,such unsavoury things as stinking lobsters and vomiting dogs, have been brought on the scene, and the sealed door of past Municipal shortcomings has been ruthlessly burst open your last correspondent .“En­trepreneur” gives us some good advice in the latter part of his letter, but it is clothed in such language as should suggest to his friends the gift of “The Polite Letter Writer" as an appropriate off ring for the coming new year; the necessity for its use might be impressed on the recipient by a suitable inscription.
All this bother seems, strings to say, to be elicited by the fact, that the town is now for the fir*t £me supplied with clean water.

A few Years ago. I saw in a French paper a very fine cartoon, in which France was re­presented by a singularly beautiful woman, of heroic proportions. She appears to have been looking into the distant futunre on the horizon, but turns her head, with a scornful expression, to some half-dozen suituors standing behind her, and says to thorn “Messieurs roes amis, dpargnez-mois, je vons eu prie ; qaant 5 mes ennemH,—je m’eQ charge I”

Modern Alexandria may well make some such rebuke to those who wrangle around her, like dogs quarrelling over a bone; for looked upon in the light of the last twenty years, the modern Alexandrian can now say, and will in a few years be able to say with still greater truth, that he is a citizen of no mean city. , We live in a time, and country, of short memories; many of the most influential people now in Alexandria were only just emerging from their cradles in 1882, when our town was reduced to a smouldering mass of ruins, and even their parents had found it more convenient to be “not at home” for a considerable while. People who really knew what’ Alexandria was reduced to at that time are getting scarcer every day.

A few days ago I saw a ship in our harbour flying the flag of a well-known British Admiral who saw all this in 1882. and mast remember the state of the place as he left; if I had the pleasure of his acquaintance should like to ask him to look round, and after taking into consideration that the progress of the last few years will, if maintained,' put np a fine sea frontage inside the beautiful quay of our Eastern harbour, to give his opinion, as to whether the town has or has not made a very respectable effort of recovery since 1882 and now, more than at any time since then, the citizens have both the wish to improve their town, and the means necessary for the purpose.
Instead of continuing to abuse each other, in a manner which is almost a disgrace to your columns, cannot we individually try to do something for the public good!

I love Alexandria for reasons which may not appeal to many people; I take a melancholy interest in revisiting the spots, where under varying circumstances, I have seen some of my friends killed, and, later on, have seen some of the enemies shot or hang, and I watch with kindly interest every step taken in the right direction, towards making this city worthy of its ancient reputation; it may not be in my town, but I feel confident that this goal will be reached, and not only that, but it will be accompanied wth the blessings of just laws and a good Government, such as ancient Alexandria could never boast.
Among other friends from whom we want to be saved, are those who have in the past so freely despoiled our town and country of the noble relics of antiquity which were its ornament.

I do not expect that anything which I may say, will induce the Venetians to send us back the body of St. Mark, or the column which they were stole from us; they might pretend that lapse of centuries gives them some shadowy sort of ownership. Our friends the French have done us so much good in the past that I do not much grudge them their obelisk of the Place de la Concordia; I am prepared to say “requiescat in pace,” but I shall always consider myself an injured individual, as long as London and New York profit by those acts of vandalism committed in recent times by the British and American Governments when they despoiled our city by the removal of the two Cleopatra needles. I regret to say that I assisted at the ceremony of the departure of both these monuments, and although there was no lack of flags flying and even of people cheering, they seemed to me very melancholy occasions, and only suggested the noble Roman exclamation, “sic transit Gloria mundi.”
I hear that the climate of the Thames embankment does not suit one of our obelisks very well, perhaps one of your American readers can tell you whether the other fares better in New York.

I hope I may live to see the day when these needles shall so prick the conscience of the respective governments, under whose shadow they have found a temporary resting place, that they will cry out “mea culpa” and send them home again.

Although modern governments may be susceptible to some such feeling, I doubt if it will go far enough to make them put their hand very far in their pocket to carry out such pions work. There may, however, be a way of getting over this. When all the towns in England and America have more books than they can read, and that time must be fast approaching, here might be a splendid opportunity for some philanthropic and wealthy gentleman to hand his name down to posterity much more effectively than by the means of some common or garden monument in a cemetery. Egypt in, with each succeeding year, taking a more conspisious place on the worlds highway. Surely a neat inscription on the base of one of these needles, when restored to their proper place, i.e. flanking our projected Municipal Palace on the quay of the Eastern harbor, is a thing worth paying for. I do not, for a moment, wish your readers to think that I have invented this idea, it must have been the main factor leading to the construction of the most famous monuments in Egypt.

When the modern Athenian feels himself inspired to beautify his city he is generally able to re assure his fellow townsmen, in words that were written some years ago on the occasion of the errection of a sacred edifice not far from Alexandria;-“from the other pockets, far shall come, the useful help, this needful sum.”

I hope I have developed my suggestion sufficiently to induce the Municipality to chalk out the proper position for the erection of the two Cleopatra needles, and perhaps they might save time by putting in the foundations.

I do not wish it to be thought that I suggest playing the game of bluff, which seems to be the fashion in central Europe just now, or even ask for a new fleet; I would on the contrary base our expectations on entirely different lines;- something more like Long fellows idea when he defends the tyrant of the family,- the baby; by saying in one of the finest lines he ever wrote;-“he ruleth by the divine of helplessness”.
Hoping that you will bring this matter to the serious attention of the British and American Governments,
I have honor to be,
“Another Alexandrian.”
Alexandria, December 1

MOSQUITOES IN EGYPT

We are pleased to hear that our leader on the "Extermination of the Mosquito” has already induced several people to institute a campaign on their premises against these pests. We can see no reason why the nuisance especially in our ports, should not be entirely abolished by the carrying out of a general crusade against the mosquito. Certainly in Egypt we are not in such a bad state as countries further south. But the abolition of the mosquito would be a great fact to this country.
A correspondant writes on this subject giving some extracts from an address on tropical medicine delivered at Leicester by Professor Bryce, FRS in July last:-

In all parts of the world practical effect is being given to the newer methods of prophylaxis. From the Federated Malay States there has been published by Dr. Watson shows that in these towns, whilst the number of deaths has been greatly reduced, increase has taken place in the district around, where no anti-malarial operation were undertaken. He further points out that the reduction has not only taken place in malaria, not also in the other diseases due in many instances to the low state of health consequent on malaria. He finally clams, and with justice. ”for the Government of Selanger the honor of being the first British Administration to follow R.ms in an attempt to confer on those entrusted to its care the benefits of his great discovery’”

From Hong Kong we have recently received the report of Dr. Atkinson for 1904. He show as the result of antimalarial measures, the following marked decrease in malarial cases. Based upon the admissions into the three hospitals. The total admissions in 1901 were 1,393; in 1902. 816; in 1903, 614; and 1904, 490. In Imailia and Havana the result are well known. From Italy, Algeria, Mexico, Brazil, and from many of our own Colonia possessions, most satisfactory reports are being constantly received.

A most striking feature of the reports of many of the South American towns is the remarkable decreased of yellow fever as the result of organised campaigns against the Stegomyia. In many places in spite of greatly improved municipal hygiene, yellow fever still made headway, and there were, in consequence, numerous critics found to draw attention to the uselessness of spending money on sanitary reforms.

With the discovery of the true cause of the spreading of yellow fever, criticism was soon disarmed by the remarkable reduction in the cases of this disease brought about by getting rid of the mosquito.

Although these results are most encouraging and are increasing in number, yet, after all, they form only a small beginning, and there yet remains an immense amount to be accomplished and a vast sea of prejudice and apathy to be got over.

At the discussion last year Dr. Stephens stated that he did not believe that one in a hundred laymen in the tropics knew that malaria was a contagious disease, or suspected the source of contagion to reside in the natives around him. That is true in a great measure to day. My experience is, for the most part, amongst those living in and trading with the West Coast, and whilst, undoubtedly, great improvement has taken place in the Gambia, Sierra Leone, and Lagor. There still exists a high percentage mortality; the young and the old trader and the miner are still indifferent, antimalarial measures are talked about but pushed on with, and still the sanitation of our oldest coast towns is a blot on our administration.

But, after all, it gives little satisfaction to any ore to complain. The problem is now being grappled with, an increasing number of the medical team officers have been especially trained, increased regard is being paid to the quarters of the white man, the use of the mosquito net is being appreciated, controlled water supplies are coming into practice, and a greatly increased number of investigators both 'at home and in the tropics are focusing attention on the tropics.

It is perhaps not very generally that “the exact boundary of Egypt towards the Turkish province of Palestine is marked by a straight line which tans from a point of the Mediterranean Sea, a little to the east of El Arish, to the head of the Golf of Akaba." This eastern boundary leaves the desert of Sinai to Egypt, but excludes the little fortress town of Akaba. Nearly the whole of the peninsula of Sinai is mountainous and has been described as “a wilderness of rocks and “mountains, -arid plains and dry beds of “torrents—a great and terrible desert” Ex­ploration and topographical survey have re­vealed marks of an astonishingly early stage of civilization, and else indications of the existence of early forms of religion, far removed from that of wandering Arab tribes. The routes of exodus did not lie entirely outside the pale of civilization. There were importantmines; at least one port of debarkation for ships coming from Egypt; the country was intersected by trade outes which were probably of extreme antiquity. A careful examination of narratives has shown thath the apparent confusion between Horeb and Sinai may be quite cleared away for the names are practically interchangeable; what the northern tribes called Horab and Sinai. Dr. Wrinkler of Berlin derives the name Sinai from the moon goddess Sin, and Horeb (lit the mountain of glowing heat) from the sun, both names thus expressing ancient cosmological conceptions. If this be so, the region of Sinai was from earliest times a place of sanctity. The history of the peninsula is as old as that of Egypt itself. The turquoise mines of Maghara and the copper mines of Sarbut el Khadem were worked by Egyptians more than 5,000 years ago. Assuming that Mt. Sanai of the Pentateuch is somewhere in the peninsula between the Gulf of Sinai and the Gulf of Akaba (Prof. Sayce has placed it outside, in the land of Midian), we have a remarkable divergence of opinion amongst critics and trevellers as to the actual mountain named in the Hebrew writings. Is Mt. Sinai of Pentateuche to be identified with Mt. Serbal, Jebel Musa or Jebel Katerina? These are questions to be discussed by experts who have studied the evidence and have personally visited and examined the localities named. After the middle of the 4th century the peninsula was gradually people with Anchorites and numerous Coenobites. On Mt. Serbal and in the Wadi Fitan there were numberless settlements of Anchorites. In the 6th century Justinian built a church half way up Jebel Musa and also constructed a strong fortress at the foot of the mountain. Since this fortress offered protection from the hermits from Wadi Fian and Mt. Serbal gradually found their way to Jebel Musa, which was now regarded as a holy place. With the spread of Islam the Anchorites gradually disappeared, the monastery of the Transfiguration alone maintaining its position.

Prof. Flinders Petrie has recently discovered, or refound, and photographed some important inscriptions at Maghara and cleared out a Semetic Temple at Sartutel Khaddem which has given unexpected light on Jewish worship and ritual.

We are looking forward to Dr. Ruffer’s lecture tonight on this most interesting and difficult subject, “the Desert of Sinai.” Among the many photographs to be placed on the screen are several of prehistoric houses and rock eut chapels.
NEW YORK LIFE INSURANCE CO.
“DISGUISING” THE BOOKS.
New York, Friday

At today’s sitting of the Insurance Investigation Committee, Mr Hughes, counsel for the committee, elicited from a clerk in the financial department of the New York Life Insurance Company to a Boston firm. This loan, witness stated, Mr. Perkins caused to be placed in a fund of which he was a trustee, and further saw to it that there should be no record of this proceeding in the books of the New York Life.
After much questioning Mr. Hughs elicited from the witness a statement that he believed the money was used to swell the fund devoted to rewarding agents for results obtained.

From the same witness Mr.Hughs learned that Mr. Hamilton, who attended to the company’s interests in regard to State legislation, received over $59,000 direct from Messrs. J.P. Morgan and Co., which represented the New York Life Insurance Company’s profits on its interest in the organization of the Unites States Steel Corporation. The company’s participation in the undertaking was disguised so as to appear to be the participation of a subsidiary company. No record of the payment was to be found in the New York Life Insurance Company’s books.
